comments.commentBody: What does it say about the Republican candidates than there are some I dread even more than Trump?  Let's start with Ted Cruz.
People who are frightened, especially.  Many of us are frightened by the degradation of job security and, indeed, jobs.

The reaction to Trump's giving voice to pent up feelings that many people have toward political correctness is akin to taking the lid off a pressure cooker.  People who have deep antipathy toward those who are different (feelings that have been repressed) have a great sense of relief when a public figure validates their own feelings.
I appreciate the honesty of admitting that we cannot compromise with fascist impulses.

I don't think calling fearful, ignorant people who express racist views as fearful and ignorant is 'demonizing' them; it's just a fact. They are fearful and ignorant and their views are racist.
Now, the Nazi appellation may be going a bit too far - but it is a convenient shorthand for people who crave an authoritarian figure who wants to blow large holes in the Bill of Rights.
As for their being infuriated and alienated ... well, perhaps they could just grow up?
Or, of course, they could stop being fearful and ignorant, but that would mean giving up their prime entertainment, which appears to be Hate Radio.
Of course there are drawbacks to immigration, just as there is an upside and we should have a rational, national discussion about it.
And maybe if the fearful ignorant mob could stop shouting about how frightened and unhappy it is, we could have it.
...rational analysis...appropriate for another time I'm afraid...

RAH and C.L.S., Americans have a good deal to be afraid of.  It's not immigrants or Muslims, it's losing their jobs and homes, or being forced to sharply lower their living standard, or losing good health care (not as bad as before the ACA but still), and so on.  these hit people where it really hurts; no displaced blame here.  The causes include the tax and wage structure that shifts income to the top1% and.1%, and the legal structure that enables large businesses to easily and profitably move their jobs to cheaper countries.

I think the consternation over Trump’s support revealing alarming xenophobia in the American people is overblown. Many people simply see no upside whatever to immigration. Educated immigrants will compete with them for jobs and with their kids for college admissions. Uneducated ones will be a burden on the system. Both kinds will drag down wages. The possibility that Muslim immigrants include terrorists is just another tick in a long ‘cons’ list, so a ‘better safe than sorry’ approach makes sense. Even 32% of Democrats (and 36% of Independents) have a negative view of the impact of immigration on the country. (http://www.pewresearch.org/fact-tank/2015/08/24/what-americans-want-to-d... These folks have no moderate candidates to represent them. Certainly there is irrational fear and racism in Trump’s support. But I think a lot of his poll numbers just reflect frustration over this issue. Demonizing these folks as racists and Nazis and condescending to them as uneducated and fearful misses the mark and only serves to infuriate and alienate them even more.

Thus, democracy is only tolerable to them as long as it doesn't threaten their demographic, economic and cultural superiority.

We'll just have to wait until they age out of the population.

The most wonderful thing about democracy, when it is working, is that different groups of people can express and live by different values and traditions. The most terrible thing about democracy, again when it is working, is that some of these views are repressive and cruel. This is to say that in the best democracies, repugnant views are visible while repugnant practices are rejected.

I believe that the most important condition of a democracy is that no group in power can be allowed to impose its views on others because of their views, traditions, or beliefs. Another way to put this is that democracy must insist on celebrating its variety and differences. Fear is no excuse, though fearful events require effective responses, which themselves must be feared and resisted.

I am appalled that so many Americans want to exercise their democratic rights by diminishing the rights of others and demonizing them. Trump is less the issue than his followers. It seems that at any time, more than one quarter of any population would prefer more authoritarian leaders and repressive practices. Our only hope, the only hope for democracy, is that it is more valuable, in all its messy complexity, than the repressions that circulate under its umbrella.

Trump just came along at the right time to do what he brags he does better than anyone:

We here inEurope are both amused and horrified...above all, mystified by what the US has become. Tens of thousands of Syrien refugees passed through Austria, thousands have asked for asylum. Even the far right Freedom party has not spewed vitriol like Trump.

The rise of Trumpism began with Trump's embrace of the birther movement. His vile persistence on that issue gave millions of Americans "permission to question who is American," in the process "redrawing the borders of respectable debate." In this election cycle, Trump has moved from the President to Mexicans, and now Muslims.

As summer turned to fall, many of us assumed Trump would go away, and become a quaint memory, like Herman Cain, perhaps. However, as we enter our winter of discontent, Trump remains front and center. At this point, my deepest hope is that there is an "after" when Trump finally exits the political stage. The possibility that Trump might actually gain the office to which he aspires is too depressing to contemplate, and not nearly as remote as it once seemed.

Life matters for how it's lived, not for its color. Asians seem to realize this, as other immigrant groups have before them. Institutions have merely accommodated that reality.

Brown University just published its early admissions results. The report bragged that of the 660+ students accepted they represented 38 states and 38 countries, dominated by China, The UK, Canada, Singapore and India. However, this claim quickly dissolves when one looks at it objectively, showing one of the problems with encouraging 'diversity' on campuses.

What was most shocking was the claim that "31 percent [of those accepted] are students of color"; this number is not shocking, until one looks at the definition of 'color': "students who self-identify as African American, Latino/a, Native American or Asian"

While I laud the Universities efforts to increase diversity it is clearly a game they wish to manipulate. It is well known that Whites and Asians (American or foreign) are over-represented on most college campuses (myself being a white male am completely aware of this). If we get rid of the "Asians" in Brown's ranking, I would wager that the 31% number would fall to well below 10%. In the US, African-Americans, Hispanics/Latinos and Native Americans or others of mixed race make up 30+% of the population. Brown has tried to match that, but by manipulating the numbers. Having a campus where " African American, Latino/a, and Native Americans" represent less than a 10th of the campus is not truly creating diversity, it is allowing tokenism.

Bruni:--"Schools should use academic requirements to make sure that students don’t travel a tract that’s too confining and idiosyncratic not just in intellectual terms but in social and demographic ones, too. For example, some science and math concentrations draw a disproportionate number of male students; if those students are not forced to take courses outside their majors, there’s a profound gender imbalance in their academic lives."

There are no purely science and math undergraduate curriculums—some humanities courses are always required. What Frank Bruni is suggesting is that, say, engineering curriculums reduce their technical courses so that the males would be "forced" to take more "feminine" courses so that the male engineering students would get greater exposure to females.

This is foolish and demeaning on so many levels. First, it means that the technical content of certain curriculum be compromised for the sake of diversity training. Second, it reflects a stereotypical view of nerdy engineering and science males needing remedial interactions with females.

Finally it is demeaning to females. Perhaps, females and minority students who concentrate in non-technical disciplines should be "forced" to take more science and math courses to create a greater mingling of genders and races as well as to better prepare them for a world in which knowledge of technology and science is key. Perhaps, Bruni believes that females and certain minorities are not up to it.

Elizabeth, no doubt the urge for religion, to connect with others in what one regards as a meaningful way, is universal, and no doubt religions tend to promote a particular mode of belief. I would contend, however, that the original impulse for all great religions is the seeking of truth through human experience. Somewhere along the way, this impulse to seek truth degenerates into an impulse to promote a more or less rigid idea of the Truth that everyone who follows a particular religion must believe. All religions succumb to this rigidity about the Truth.

However, that original impulse to seek truth is still alive and sustaining to us, and works its way around and through the rigid encumbrances with which human culture inevitably tends to surround it. Unfortunately, these encumbrances sometimes create damaging road blocks that threaten the health and survival of individuals and whole societies. Yet, it is this still living impulse, given sufficient scope and enough people to sustain it, that eventually clears a path through some of our most damaging efforts to thwart it.

The fact of our continued efforts to keep the path to truth open provides reasons for optimism that we will overcome our worst. However, the ultimate outcome remains uncertain, and that in itself provides motivation to keep working for that opening.

The accusation, and it's not an unreasonable one, is that the first woman president ideally is somebody who got there entirely on her own, not by being hitched to the right man. Think about it this way: Without Bill, would you be considering voting for Ms Clinton? Probably not, because it's quite possible that she would not have become known outside of the Arkansas bar association.

In other words, why settle for Clinton when we could instead be rallying around many of the fine women in the Democratic caucus who got there primarily by their own efforts? Why are we treating Hillary Clinton as a feminist icon when we could instead be celebrating the work of female senators who have much longer public service like Barbara Mikulski, Barbara Boxer, Dianne Feinstein, and Patty Murray? Or Elizabeth Warren, who more than anyone else was able to turn the concerns of Occupy Wall Street into public policy?

Liberal democracy requires that ordinary citizens, at least in the aggregate, make rational decisions. It relies on citizens educating themselves and being able to separate truth from fiction.

Religion requires that we "believe" in fictions. The dominant religions require that we believe fictions that have been disproved over millennia. Many of them required that we submit to the authority of unelected leaders.

So indeed, religion, any religion, is inimical to liberal democracy.

Is it true to say "Islam, as practiced today in Saudi Arabia, Iran and Pakistan, is inimical to liberal democracy"?

Is it true to say "Christianity, as practiced today in the United States, is inimical to liberal democracy"?

This scripture-reading is no help in providing an answer to the above two questions, and that is what people want answered.

Perhaps Bill McKibbon of 350.org said it best today, "This didn't save the planet, but it may have saved the chance of saving the planet."

If you read this newspaper, Western Europe appears to be the only place with a better model of society, and all other countries are full of problems. Why is it so surprising that students choose Western Europe when offered the opportunity to study abroad?

Nearly forty years of working on college campuses, as an African American professor, I have grown soul-weary with the effort to place multi-cultural education on the shoulders of students. You want a diverse campus? Diversify the faculty, the administration and the curriculum. Students do not arrive on a campus already trained to articulate the intricacies of their cultural heritages. How could they? Teachers have the responsibility to teach the "true truth" about all the cultures we have have studied -- and to use our knowledge to help guide our students into becoming transformative leaders. When they arrive, relatively unaware, it is our responsibility to know more than they do. Students should not be forced to teach those who are paid to transmit cultural treasures.

It wasn't just "a black man". Obama has shown time and time again that he's a smart guy, and he's done a lot as president that has made a lot of lives better.

For example, thanks to Obama, I knew I was going to be able to get individual health insurance coverage, and thus felt comfortable making the transition from full-time employee to entrepreneur. And my city is in the process of rebuilding a major highway bridge that had been falling apart for years. This stuff makes real differences in all our lives.
